abstract: Investment research firm MSCI reports uptick in business driven by investor demand for information related to so-called ESG factors--environmental, social and corporate governance; global research chief Linda-Eling Lee says investors use her company's data and ratings to find risks from poor levels of director independence, regulatory warnings and liabilities and other factors overlooked by traditional analysis; trend underscores growing investor ideology that corporations with good ESG factors are better investments.

headline.print_headline: Investor Demand Leads Analysts to Focus on Stocks’ Social and Environmental Risks
headline.main: Investors Sharpen Focus on Social and Environmental Risks to Stocks

snippet: MSCI’s social index business grows as big pensions and other investors pour money into funds that focus on more than just corporate balance sheets....
lead_paragraph: MSCI’s social index business grows as big pensions and other investors pour money into funds that focus on more than just corporate balance sheets.
